#Text=In the Andes
#Text=Professor Swyington Bumper seemed to live in a region all by himself .

#Text=Though he was on board the Bellaconda , he might just as well have been in an airship , or riding along on the back of a donkey , as far as his knowledge , or recognition , of his surroundings went .
#Text=He seemed to be thinking thoughts far , far away , and he was never without a book -- either a bound volume or a note-book .
#Text=In the former he buried his hawk-like nose , and Tom , looking over his shoulder once , saw that the book was printed in curious characters , which , later , he learned were Sanskrit .
#Text=If he had a note-book the bald-headed professor was continually jotting down memoranda in it .
#Text=" I can hardly think of him as a conspirator against us , " said Tom to Mr. Titus .
#Text=" After you have been in the contracting business as long as I have you 'll distrust every one , " was the answer .
#Text=" Waddington is n't on board , or I 'd distrust him .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=But Professor Bumper proved to be above suspicion .

#Text= He is making a search for something , but he wo n't say what it is , " the captain said .

column1: #Text=" At first we thought it was gold or jewels , for he goes away off into the Andes Mountains , where both gold and jewels have been found .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= What is he after then ? " asked Mr. Titus .

column1: #Text=" No one knows , and he wo n't tell .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= This is quite a mystery , " remarked Tom .

column1: #Text=" It certainly is .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= This seems to dispose of the theory that he planted the bomb , and that he is one of the plotters in the pay of Blakeson & Grinder , " said Mr. Titus , when he and Tom were alone .

column1: #Text=" Yes , I guess it does .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=That was a question neither could answer .

#Text=

_	_	_	_

#Text=Well , unless the bomb fell from some passing airship , I do n't see how it got on deck ,  said Tom with a shake of his head .

column1: #Text=They had kept the matter secret , not telling even Mr. Damon , for they feared the eccentric man would make a fuss and alarm the whole vessel .
#Text=So Mr. Damon , occasionally blessing his necktie or his shoe laces , played chess with his elderly gentleman friend and was perfectly happy .
#Text=That Professor Bumper not only had kept his promise about not mentioning the bomb , but that he had forgotten all about it , was evident a day or two after the happening .
#Text=Tom and Mr. Titus passed him on deck , and bowed cordially .
#Text=The professor returned the salutation , but looked at the two in a puzzled sort of fashion .
#Text=" I beg your pardon , " he remarked , " but your faces are familiar , though I cannot recall your names .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= You have , " said Tom , with a smile .

column1: #Text=" You saved our lives from a bomb the other day . "
#Text=" Oh , yes !

#Text=There have n't been any more bombs thrown at us ,  the contractor said .

#Text= By the way , Professor Bumper , I understand you are quite a traveler in the Andes , in the vicinity of Lima . "

column1: #Text=" Yes , I have been there , " admitted the bald-headed scientist in guarded tones .

#Text=" Well , I am digging a tunnel in that vicinity , " went on Mr. Titus , " and if you ever get near Rimac , where the first cutting is made , I wish you would come and see me -- Tom too , as he is associated with me . "
#Text=" Rimac-Rimac , " murmured the professor , looking sharply at the contractor .
#Text=" Digging a tunnel there ?
